itemDescription: Archdeacon of Halifax; Bishop of Pontefract; Bishop of St Edmundsbury and Ipswich (1898-1977)

wikipedia_page.main: Arthur Harold Morris (20 February 1898 – 15 October 1977) was an Anglican bishop in the 20th century.

response: |align="center"| 1949 ||align="center"| 1954 || Arthur Morris || Canon and Archdeacon, 1946. Subsequently Bishop of St Edmundsbury and Ipswich, 1954–65.

link_mentions.page: Bishop of St Edmundsbury and Ipswich

response: Kirkham was made a deacon at Michaelmas 1962 (30 September) at St Mary's, Woodbridge and ordained a priest the Michaelmas following (29 September 1963) at St Mary-le-Tower, Ipswich — both times by Arthur Morris, Bishop of St Edmundsbury and Ipswich. His ministry began with a curacy at St Mary-le-Tower, Ipswich, after which he was Chaplain to Launcelot Fleming, Bishop of Norwich.Crockford's Clerical Directory2008/2009 Lambeth,Church House Publishing () From 1970 to 1972, he was an assistant priest at St Martin-in-the-Fields and St Margaret's, Westminster. Finally, before his appointment to the episcopate, he was Director of Ordinands in the Diocese of Canterbury and Domestic Chaplain to Archbishop of Canterbury.‘Kirkham, John Dudley Galtrey’, Who's Who 2012, A & C Black, 2012; online edition, Oxford University Press, December 2011 , accessed 5 July 2012
Brook’s successor, Arthur Morris, was among the most popular and pastoral of bishops.
Arthur Morris (1922–2015) was an Australian cricketer.
Arthur Morris may also refer to:
* Arthur Morris (U.S. Army officer) (1843–1892), officer in the United States Army
*1946–1954 (res.): Arthur Morris, Bishop suffragan of Pontefract
